p: For the most part, global trends in environmental conditions have declined since 1970, due largely to increased anthropogenic drivers of environmental decline. For example, greenhouse-gas concentrations, ocean acidification, and soil fertility have worsened with increases in greenhouse-gas emissions and land uses that degrade soil ( 38). There are some exceptions to declining environmental quality. For example, air quality, as measured by concentrations of particulate matter ≤2.5 μm, has generally improved in high-income countries, where concerted efforts have reduced air-pollution emissions ( 39). However, since 1970, air quality has declined, often significantly, in many low- and middle-income countries due to increasing emissions ( 39). Without the regulating contributions of nature, however, the decline in many environmental conditions would likely have been larger.
